reviewText:
First off, I'll say that this is a mobile game ported to PC and 2 hours I'm really enjoying it. Anyone who's played Silent Hunter will recognize parts of the interface. I believe they used the SH3 engine for this, or they really loved it's interface.

Going through the tutorials I've been taught how to maneuver and fire on mostly harmless AI merchant's with a destroyer, battleship, a carrier (it's aircraft) and a submarine. All which play a bit differently.

The game is turn based and has phases. You have a movement phase and then an action phase. Movement is self explanatory, but action is where you'll fire your guns, torpedoes or ready / launch aircraft (you can only do one action per turn). So, you move then act, then the enemy moves then acts.

It has an interesting firing system. You target an enemy (with a somewhat clunky targetting system) which gives you an estimate on it's range and the elevation you should set your guns to. Your first volley will more than likely miss,  but the game gives you tools to estimate how to modify the elevation of your guns to get a hit with the next volley. Your aim increasingly gets better the more volleys you fire in a row on the same target. I'll also add that the guns are not totally accurate so even if you have the perfect elevation, your shots might not always hit. There are also options for duds, wind to effect your shots

The game has a fairly detailed damage model as well. You can hit and destroy certain parts of the ships, knock out their guns, rudder, AA, Radar, etc. It's rather surprising to see so much detail in this. Some times a ship can shrug off dozens of rounds and others can go down with a single, critical hit. Plunging fire seems highly destructive, my first heavy cruiser I bought was destroyed with the plunging fire from an enemy destroyer in the opening volley.. I had to take a break after that.

Ships have certain armor values for different parts of their ships. Battleships will have thick belt, turret and deck armor while destroyers and torpedo boats have virtually nothing (making them highly vulnerable to HE ammo). The first heavy cruiser I bought in the Allied campaign was destroyed in the first opening volley by an enemy destroyer.. so,

Destroyers and submarines and yes cruisers have torpedoes which you'll decide where each torpedo travels in a spread. You could decide to have them all in one spot, or have a wide spread guaranteeing a hit on the target. In most cases they require time to target which varies depending on the ship / what torpedoes it's firing. Usually it takes 1 full turn to land CLOSE shots (within 2500 meters or so, I'm not entirely certain yet) which gives the enemy a turn to try and maneuver away from them. They also have a 1,000 meter arming distance, so you can't hug enemy ships for easy torpedoes.

In the campaign mode, you're given 6000 Prestige at first to purchase your starting fleet, so this is sort of like Victory at Sea. I decided to go with the Kriegsmarine, so my first vessel purchased was a Type 1934A Class Destroyer. So far it looks like there are 19 different ship types for the Kriegsmarine.

From the PDF Manual:

There is a weather system and the missions seem to (at random) change between night and day which effects your vision range and accuracy which I find helps the replayability. Not every fight is in bright sunlight with perfect conditions. I'd recommend playing this with as much realism as possible as it seems a bit TOO easy at first.

reviewText:
I've spent the better part of the evening trying out various scenarios and ships just to please my inner sailor and I have to say this game is a load of fun.

I've spent way too long playing the battle of the Denmark Straight as the Germans (sent both Hood and Prince of Wales to the bottom, though at the cost of Prinz Eugen at least once). Been working on trying to figure out exactly where Hood's main magazine is to fully recreate that bit.

I've sent HMS Barham to the bottom using a U-boat.

Had a fictious duel between the Showboat (USS North Carolina) and the Kreigsmarine Scharnhoarst in which Scharnhoarst got left a flaming hulk that refused to sink. And many other duels and matches that my mind is working on.

Now down to brass tacks:

What it is good at:
Naval gun fire: the game isn't going to hold your hand, you will need to figure out the angles you are firing at to have best effect.

Visuals are very pleasing.

Parts of the ships are capable of being disabled.

Nice variety of ships ranging from Battleships down to destroyers and merchant ships.

Cons:
Aircraft are difficult to use
Torpedos operate on their own turn, which can lead to some odd timings (particularly with torpedo bombers) and they don't have a huge range.


All in all?

Great if you really enjoy surface warfare and really want to channel your inner Kreigsmarine in the Bismarck and go to down while listening to old German military music. Or English, whichever.

This has been my best purchase in a long time, I can't recommend it enough.

reviewText:
I like the idea of WW2  naval games but I have almost always been disapointed in recent years, there isn't really anything out there currently that is half way realistic.
This was reasonably priced but I didn't really expect much.

What a huge suprise, this is a great game and despite my low expectations because of its mobile origins, is more accurate  than other recent games about WW2 naval combat that I have played  (eg WOS...Victory at...etc.).

Its fairly simple to play  but is really well featured,  has a really good gunnery mechanic that feels quite authentic and puts the 'game' into the title.  Plus many other essentials , eg starshells at night, smoke screens , carriers and ground based aircraft.
Submarines are significant as they should be in something about the battle of the Atlantic, the game also has destroyers with the various ASW systems to fight them,

It reminds me of the early SSI type naval games that were intended as simulations. Its the only thing that has come close in a long time anyhow.

Hopefully the developers do well enough to develp this further, with multiplayer and a scenario editor, this will be hands down the most authentic modern WW2 naval game current.

reviewText:
Atlantic Fleet is an Android app game that has been ported to PC. It does have a few menu issues here and there otherwise it is an EXTREMELY good port and one of the best I've seen of a mobile phone port. If you couldn't tell from the image and name, you control a fleet from one of two factions (or two as you can control both sides, and for the first time in a while, a game that actually has local multiplayer i.e. the person sitting next to you). The game takes a lot of practice to get a hold of and I highly recommend you go through the tutorial missions as they are A. Not too long and B. You can quit out of them at any time if you think you've understood. They also don't have any spoken dialogue which you can say is bad but it means that the tutorials are not on a set scripted path. You get placed in the sea, in control of the British Battleship Queen Elizabeth, Destroyers’ Jervis and Afridi or Carrier Courageous and told through text at the bottom of the screen what to do in the tutorial.

The tutorials are very well put together as they tell you what everything does and how things affect everything. The game takes Naval realism seriously and don't expect to hit the enemy ships first time, every time. You may get lucky once or twice, but don't get cocky or mad when you hit/miss. Gun caliber, movement by your ship, their ship and on hard mode the wind can all affect your distance and everything else.

It is turn based so don't expect RT combat. I think that would just cause havoc. Yes it can be hard to get into because turns can be excruciatingly long and tedious, but its turn based so what do you expect.

The two factions are:
British and Commonwealth navies. FT. USA
German navy.

Pros: (Out of 3 +)
Very good and well put together port +++
Accurate ships +++
Hard to get good at, extremely hard to master +

Cons: (Out of 3 -)
Only two factions ---
Some graphical bugs with text boxes in the tutorials when playing at a lower resolution and windowed - Excused because that’s just being nitpicky.

This game is extremely good and a worthwhile pick up even at its full price. Yes it may be a mobile phone port and that may put you off. However it is a really good game, I know surprising there are good mobile phone ports. All this game needs is expansion to its factions and even to the existing factions with more ships or etc. Yes the game is limited to one theater, the Atlantic, (although there is a mission where you are fighting off the coast of Australia so... OK?) However there is room for two more or even four more factions. My idea is this:

Allies:
UK and Commonwealth Navies * Expanded upon
US Navy * Expanded greatly upon
French Navy
Soviet Union Navy

Axis:
German and puppet state Navies (i.e. Slovakia, Belgium, Netherlands etc.)
Italian and puppet state Navies (i.e. Yugoslavia, Albania)
Romanian Navy
Bulgarian Navy

Again, besides my recommendations, this game is very good and the best Atlantic Naval battle simulator I've seen and more a mobile phone port it blows my mind. A definite must buy.

**SIDE NOTE**
I purposefully left out the campaign, in my review, as I haven't played much of the campaign and probably wont'. Not because it is bad but just because I just want to blow ships up without having to rank up ships or go through any of that. If you want to you can go right ahead.
**SIDE NOTE**

8.95 / 10 - So close to a 10, just needs more content to mess around with. The foundations are great, just needs expansion upon those foundations.

One of the best games I've ever got on steam TBH. Graphics are excellent, game content is exciting (and historical) and also refreshingingly differant and there is a good tutorial too which is well worth going through as there are some new forms of combat I've not seen before.
The setting for this hybrid naval strategy 1st/3rd person shooter, simulation is the Battle of the Atlantic between British/CW naval forces and the German Kriegsmarine. This is a nice change from the Pacific TBH, which has been very heavily covered already, though I'm sure the devs will eventually move the action to the Pacific/Indian Ocean as an add-on, hopefully the Mediterranean too.
You get to play either side in single missions or campaign mode, and your forces comprise of every type of surface warship from destroyers up to battleships and aircraft carriers. Cargo vessels and even German commerce raiders that look like cargo vessels are included. The sinking graphics are amazing and you'll see and hear the stricken vessel slowly plummet towards the sea bed by taking your camera underwater as it sinks. Also included is a good range of historical aircraft from carrier planes through to long range maritime aircraft based on land. The types of combat you can expect to perform as the player are:

1. Gunnery 3rd person.
2. Torpedo attacks 1st and 3rd person.
3. Depth charge/hedgehog attacks against subs 3rd person (very well done)
4. Dive bombing with carrier aircraft 3rd person
5. Torpedo bombing with carrier aircraft 3rd person
6. Level bombing with multi engine bombers 3rd person

Like the excellent Battle Fleet 2" the devs have chosen to keep the game from becoming a manic clickfest by utilising a good turn based system whereby there are movement and action phases for each vessel. This works really well especially when you have multiple assets under command
date: and allows you to plan tactics and strategy.\nI'm currently in the RN campaign and it's a lot of fun. Basically you start off by buying a destroyer with your available war bonds and to add further ships to your fleet you'll need to sink enemy tonnage to be rewarded with more war bonds. In my first try I'd graduated to 2 destroyers
recommended: a Fido class cruiser and a light escort carrier carrying Swordfish strike planes. All was going swimmingly until I was ambushed by U-boats and made a mess of my defence and now I'm back at the Admiralty rather sheepishly asking for enough war bonds to start over again!\nEven though the game is not complete yet I definitely recommended AF already."

reviewText:
I bought this on an impulse, as it was cheap, featured WWII naval combat, and looked pretty good.
My first impression is not all that great, however. Putting shots on target is a lot more hit and miss than it feels it ought to be. In-game estimates meant to help you with this are often wildly off the mark, making combat rather frustrating. Also, I find I have a bit of trouble keeping track of the battlefield during night battles, as there are no interface prompts or icons that let you know which of the ships are yours and which are enemies (on the map, yes, but in 3D mode not so much).

I need more time to come to grips with this game, but even as a cheap impulse purchase I am not overly happy. I was hoping for an off-line alternative for World of Warships, but this offers a lot less satisfaction/hour than WoWS.

At this stage I am neither recommending this game, nor am I saying you should not buy it if you are into WWII naval combat. I will say that it isn't a very intuitive game, and had me frustrated in under 15 minutes. I want to like it, I just don't. Not yet, at least.

If you see this game as 'Total War: WW2 Navy' you will get its concept immediately - the strategy map is there to move around units, repair and refuel etc, and the main fun is in the battles - although they are turn based not real time, although some aspects like animations and ships sinking are done in real time - its a bit weird but it works! And the battles are remarkable with plenty of deep gameplay - I especially love the torpedo plane runs and try to ram the subs which is more difficult than it sounds.

The custom game on its own is worth the money - had loads of fun pitting a Flower Class Corvette against a U-Boat like in the film the Cruel Sea. And if you want to see what HMS Nelson against the Graf Spee would be like you can do that as well along with practically every type of other ship.

But the main fun is in the dynamic campaign - kudos to the devs for putting that in! Its really addictive. Yes the missions are great but the dynamic campaign is where the game shines - you never know what you are going to meet - U-boats or battleships or cruisers etc and you get differing weather and time of day. The weather moves in a realistic manner. The game features ballistics, damage control, smoke, torpedoes, Swordfish, hedgehogs, squid - you name it its all in here.

As yet it never gets overwhelming - managing a sub and firing a spread of torpedoes is really easy, flying a low level torpedo plane attack is dramatic, takes skill but its also scary, but not complicated. Learning to get the range of that distant battleship before it gets yours is similarly nervewracking and exciting - its easy to get to grips with the mechanics but actually doing it takes experience.

Best buy I have made for years. Its a simple game with loads of depth, loads of accuracy and surprisingly deep mechanics, and the dynamic campaign means it will stay fresh for a long time. And for £6 its a steal, it should be at least £20.

An excellent WW2 naval simulation, very good value for money and a worthy successor to the old 'Fighting Steel' game.
The turn-based system is easy to learn, gunnery and torpedoes are simulated well but I am less impressed with the aircraft simulation. Or maybe I haven't got the hang of it yet!
A wide variety of ships are available for the Royal Navy and the Kriegsmarine plus a few for the USN but there are some notable absences; German 'Wolf' and 'Seeadler' torpedo boats, the disguised raider 'Thor', British armed merchant cruisers and 'Hunt' class destroyers, American destroyer escorts would all be good additions (DLC pack maybe, pretty please Killerfish Games?).
Also, Atlantic Fleet could easily form the basis for further games set in the Mediterranean  (Battle of Cape Matapan, Force K just for a start) or the First World War (Coronel, The Falklands, Emden vs Sydney, the Dover Patrol, I could go on but I won't).
Highly recommended and very addictive.

This game is amazing in it's detail and realism. I haven't played a better PC representation of the Atlantic battles. You get submarine, surface, and air action plus two campaigns! This is no arcade game. It is not easy to get your shots on target until you realistically adjust gun elevation and allow for wind.

One point, the manual isn't right about the keystroke for the ESC key to bring up the menu. That is done by clicking the small curly arrow in the bottom left corner. That's how you exit the game. It saves automatically after a battle or ship launch. Yes, you can purchase additional ships in the campaign games.

Thoroughly enjoyable.
